title: 109_s4051
content:
The Act titled "Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Oversight and Resource Enhancement Act of 2006" focuses on enhancing resources and personnel for electronic surveillance for foreign intelligence purposes. It includes provisions related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court matters. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to allow the Chief Justice of the United States to designate additional judges for the court established under the Act. The Chief Justice can designate additional judges for the court to ensure prompt consideration of electronic surveillance applications. A judge must decide on applications within 24 hours of receipt. SEC. 102. ADDITIONAL PERSONNEL FOR PREPARATION AND CONSIDERATION OF APPLICATIONS FOR ORDERS APPROVING ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE. The Office of Intelligence Policy and Review of the Department of Justice is authorized additional personnel, including at least 21 full-time attorneys, to prepare applications for electronic surveillance orders under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. These personnel will be assigned to the National Security Agency to assist in the application process. The Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Security Branch is authorized additional legal and other personnel to prepare applications for electronic surveillance orders under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The Director of the FBI will assign these personnel to field offices to assist in the application process. The National Security Agency and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court are authorized additional legal and other personnel to facilitate the prompt preparation and consideration of applications for electronic surveillance orders under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The National Security Agency and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court are authorized additional legal and other personnel to facilitate the prompt preparation and consideration of applications for electronic surveillance orders under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. Personnel approved under this act will perform duties directed by the Court for the consideration of such applications. This personnel is supplementary and not a replacement for any other authorized personnel by law. The Director of the FBI and NSA, in consultation with the Attorney General, must develop regulations for electronic surveillance on an emergency basis under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. They must also provide related training for agency personnel. Additionally, there is an extension of the period for applications for orders for emergency electronic surveillance. Section 105(f) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act is amended to extend the time for emergency electronic surveillance from 72 hours to 168 hours. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act is amended to allow electronic surveillance of foreign communications without a court order. If a communication involving a domestic party is inadvertently collected, it must be handled according to minimization procedures. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 allows electronic surveillance of foreign communications without a court order, with terms like "contents", "electronic surveillance", and "foreign intelligence information" defined in the Act. SEC. 203 prohibits the retention or use of wire or radio communications sent from inside the US to outside without a FISA court order. SEC. 204 clarifies that FISA provisions for communications from outside to inside the US remain unchanged, with the courts determining the constitutionality of such interceptions. TITLE III focuses on enhanced congressional oversight and Supreme Court review of the terrorist surveillance program. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include additional provisions for electronic surveillance. The Attorney General is required to inform congressional intelligence committees semiannually about surveillance conducted without a court order. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to allow the Chair of congressional intelligence committees to inform members of reports on a bipartisan basis. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to allow the Chair of congressional intelligence committees to inform members of reports on a bipartisan basis, as deemed necessary. The Supreme Court will review the legality of the Terrorist Surveillance Program upon appeal, with expedited consideration. The program intercepts international communications of individuals linked to terrorist organizations. TITLE IV--OTHER MATTERS

SEC. 401. DEFINITION.

    Defines "Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court" as the court established by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978.

SEC. 402. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    Authorizes necessary funds for implementing this Act and its amendments.

SEC. 403. EFFECTIVE DATE.

    This Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment.
